title: New flag parsing breaks restic?
body:
<!--

If you've just got a question or aren't sure if you've found a bug then please use the rclone forum

    https://forum.rclone.org/

instead of filing an issue.  We'll reply quickly and it won't increase our massive issue backlog.

    https://beta.rclone.org/
    
If you can still replicate it with the latest beta, then please fill in the info below which makes our lives much easier.  A log with -vv will make our day :-)

Thank you very much for all you hard work!

#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

By default, restic [calls rclone](https://github.com/restic/restic/blob/master/internal/backend/rclone/backend.go#L143-L145) like this:
```
rclone serve restic --stdio --b2-hard-delete --drive-use-trash=false
```

Since yesterday, our integration tests break, rclone [exits with an error message](https://travis-ci.com/restic/restic/jobs/135026826#L583):

```
rclone: Error: invalid argument "--drive-use-trash=false" for "--b2-hard-delete" flag: parsing "--drive-use-trash=false" as bool failed: expected newline
```

I saw that you removed the `pflag` library. It looks like all the boolean flags now need an explicit `true` or `false` value, this seems to work:

```
rclone serve restic --stdio --b2-hard-delete=true --drive-use-trash=false
```

Was this breaking change intentional (not meant as an accusation, just curious)? I know that `pflag` has too many options for its own good :)

Do you have an idea on how to mitigate this (also from restic's point of view)? At the moment, the default arguments for `rclone` are hard-coded into the restic binary, but can be overwritten by command-line flags. I'm fearing that users will use an older restic binary with a fresh rclone binary and it won't work out of the box, is there anything we can do?

#### What is your rclone version (eg output from `rclone -V`)

```
rclone v1.42-DEV
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.10.3
```


#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)

Linux, amd64


####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)

Local

#### The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

rclone serve restic --stdio --b2-hard-delete --drive-use-trash=false
